Project Introduction

The Avatar: The Last Airbender mobile game was released in 2023 for both iOS and Android platforms and was built using Unity. I have been part of the team since the project's inception, contributing to the creation of the design proposal deck for Square Enix. As a UI/UX designer, I played a key role in managing complex UX flows that involved multiple teams. I closely collaborated with other designers to enhance the game's overall quality.

Roles

UI/UX Design

Tools

Photoshop/ XD/ Invision/ Figma

Engine

Unity

Getting started

  1. Getting Started - Understanding the Game's Genre:

    I began by understanding the genre of the game and gathering all the necessary resources. I downloaded apps from our competitors and started playing them. I also consulted the game director to get recommendations on which games to download for reference.

  2. Understanding the Target Audience:

    Since the cartoon is old and popular, most of the users are big fans of the Avatar series. To connect with them, I watched the entire cartoon series to understand the story behind it.

  3. Continuously Searching for UI Design References:

    Before starting the project, I always searched for references for UI elements. I like to Google them, check Pinterest and Behance.

  4. Learning About the Game Engine:

    I believe it's important for a designer to understand how UI is implemented in the engine. Therefore, I worked diligently to grasp how the game engine operates.

Design Ideas

Challenge

Nickelodeon didn't want the game to resemble the cartoon. So, as a UI/UX designer, I conducted extensive research and testing to create a fresh design that our players would appreciate. I developed detailed plans and paper prototypes to showcase our ideas to our partners, including Nickelodeon and Square Enix. However, we encountered a challenge - the version of Unity we were using didn't support responsive. As a result, I had to adapt everything to fit into a 4:3 ratio, which proved to be quite challenging task.

Key Words

UI Elements

Grid

The game supports iOS and Android, and the largest platform screen ratio is 4:3 (tablet). It's important to ensure that the design fits within this 4:3 ratio, and we can use anchor points to make elements expand appropriately across different platforms.

Typeface

Consider using a limited number of font styles. For headers, utilize the Avatar style font, while for body text, opt for a more standard font to ensure readability.

Icons

Design universal icons for use in the game. Keep them as simple as possible since they'll be placed within the app. Conduct in-house user testing to determine the best appearance. Additionally, consider adding tooltips to the icons to help users.

Userflow

This is a basic user flowchart that explains how a player enters the game and lands in the lobby screen. Every time I work on a task, I create a small flowchart to share with the team so that we are aligned with the plan.

Breakdown Components

As a UX designer, my primary responsibility is to provide comprehensive guidelines for both the engineering and art teams. Ensure alignment with all teams involved.

List Tab State
Anchoring Info

Due to technical restriction, I start to create mockup with a 4:3 ratio. This anchoring mockup show how the layout will expand as the screen size increases. It's important to note that our current game engine doesn't accommodate responsive design. The width stretches based on the anchoring points while the height remains fixed.

Event Challenge Screen

Remove unimportant text or hide certain information behind the info button. Allow users to concentrate on the events listed. The Gacha and Shop buttons are crucial for sales, so I needed to identify a location that is both prominent yet not overwhelming or conflicting with other elements.
